dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So the National Bank of Kazakhstan is holding firm at 16.5 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So the National Bank of Kazakhstan is holding firm at sixteen point five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Kazakhstan's National Bank has decided to keep the base rate at 16.5 percent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, they just announced that on Friday, right? The Monetary Policy Committee decided to keep it steady.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, they just announced that on Friday, right? The Monetary Policy Committee decided to keep it steady.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On Friday, April 11, the Monetary Policy Committee of the National Bank announced its decision to maintain the annual base rate at 16.5 percent, with an interest rate corridor of +/- 1 percentage point.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, and they're citing high inflation risks and external uncertainty as the main reasons. They don't see conditions for a cut anytime soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, and they're citing high inflation risks and external uncertainty as the main reasons. They don't see conditions for a cut anytime soon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the current balance of inflation factors, the pace of inflation, pro-inflationary trends, and high external uncertainty, conditions are not yet in place for lowering the base rate in the near term," the National Bank stated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which makes sense, because that base rate is really their primary tool for controlling inflation—it affects everything from loans to savings.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which makes sense, because that base rate is really their primary tool for controlling inflation-it affects everything from loans to savings.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The central bank uses the base rate to regulate the money supply and, ultimately, inflation. By raising or lowering the rate, the regulator influences economic activity.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and at 16.5%, borrowing is expensive, which should theoretically slow down spending and cool off price increases.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and at sixteen point five percent, borrowing is expensive, which should theoretically slow down spending and cool off price increases.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Conversely, raising the rate helps curb inflation by reducing the money supply and encouraging savings over spending and investment.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But it's a tough balance, isn't it? Because keeping rates high for too long could also stifle economic growth.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But it's a tough balance, isn't it? Because keeping rates high for too long could also stifle economic growth.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A lower rate injects more money into the economy, making loans cheaper for businesses, increasing investments, and stimulating economic growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. And they mentioned the next review isn't until June 5th of next year, so we're in for a wait.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. And they mentioned the next review isn't until June fifth of next year, so we're in for a wait.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The next scheduled decision on the base rate by the Monetary Policy Committee will be announced on June 5, 2025, at 12:00 P.M.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a long time to maintain such a high rate. I wonder how businesses are coping with those lending costs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a long time to maintain such a high rate. I wonder how businesses are coping with those lending costs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's gotta be challenging, especially for smaller enterprises looking to expand or invest.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's gotta be challenging, especially for smaller enterprises looking to expand or invest.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And on the currency side, a high rate might support the tenge by attracting foreign capital, at least in the short term.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And on the currency side, a high rate might support the tenge by attracting foreign capital, at least in the short term.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A reduction in the base rate may weaken the national currency in the short term, as cheaper money can prompt investors to sell off tenge assets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Though the National Bank did note that lowering it could weaken the currency initially, before any growth benefits kick in.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Though the National Bank did note that lowering it could weaken the currency initially, before any growth benefits kick in.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A reduction in the base rate may weaken the national currency in the short term, as cheaper money can prompt investors to sell off tenge assets.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's all about timing and reading those economic indicators carefully.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's all about timing and reading those economic indicators carefully.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The National Bank adjusts the rate based on economic indicators, using it as a primary tool of monetary policy.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Monetary policy is never just a simple lever—it's a whole ecosystem of trade-offs.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Monetary policy is never just a simple lever-it's a whole ecosystem of trade-offs.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and with global markets being so volatile, I can see why they're playing it safe for now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and with global markets being so volatile, I can see why they're playing it safe for now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given the current balance of inflation factors, the pace of inflation, pro-inflationary trends, and high external uncertainty, conditions are not yet in place for lowering the base rate in the near term," the National Bank stated.
